newsitem.title: USA: Daimler-Benz may pull out of China deal - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Daimler-Benz may pull out of China deal - WSJ.

text.p: Daimler-Benz AG is threatening to abandon a $1 billion joint venture in China to build minivans because of disagreements with the Chinese government, the Wall Street Journal said on Friday.

In its electronic edition, the Journal said the company's Mercedes-Benz division wants to build a single plant, while its partner, state-run Nanfang South China Motor Corp., wants to build two separate assembly plants.
Since the deal was cut in 1995, China also has changed conditions in the agreement, the Journal said.

The paper quoted Jurgen Hubbert, the Daimler-Benz board member who oversees worldwide passenger car sales, as saying Mercedes will withdraw from China if the issues cannot be resolved. However, Hubbert also said the company is trying to resolve those issues with its partner.
"We want to stay, because it's one of the most important markets ... but not for any price," Hubbert said. "If we see we won't make our targets, we'll stop" the project.
An unnamed U.S. auto executive familiar with the situation told the Journal, "The deal is effectively dead."
